pros: The medical and surgical care given to patients at WakeMed is incredible. The people of Wake County don’t understand how lucky they are to have such talented people working at a community hospital. There’s a nice mixed atmosphere of MDs, residents, and APPs sharing the workload.
cons: As most businesses, money is a huge factor here. There is no good way to say that APPs are underpaid and overworked, but we are. I have worked at WakeMed for over 10 years and I’ve seen how my attending physicians lives have gotten easier and easier while the workload of the APP has gotten harder. I do not feel we are fairly compensated, not only for the work that we do, but the actual revenue that we produce. It feels like the main goal is to make as much money as possible with the smallest workforce. This had lead to burnout across the board.

job_title: RN, Staff Nurse in Raleigh, NC
pros:
I have worked at WakeMed over 10 years.  The reason I came was for the Childrens' Emergency Department.  The reason I stayed though was because of all the support and kindness I have found there.  Not just my department, but the whole system really follows the Wake Way = be helpful wherever you can.  

Smile and take that lost soul by the hand and lead them where they need to be.  Whether that is a patient, family member, vendor, poor lost new employee or what.  I know that without the help of WakeMed employees I would still be wandering the halls, trying to find my department. 

The staff is excellent, providing excellent care.  No worries about being a patient there for myself, my family, my friends.
Many places provide excellent care, but WakeMed makes sure you feel the caring that goes with the care.
cons: The biggest downside is the constant construction.  While I know it is necessary, it is still frustrating to find a hallway disappeared over the weekend.  And parking is a pain, also due to construction.  When it is completed though we will be so glad.  And we don't have to pay for it.  I understand that some places (where my sister worked) employees have to pay for parking.

review_title: An okay place to work for a little while...
pros: Good work/life balance.  Coworkers are fantastic, reliable, and knowledgeable.  Decent benefits package.  Onsite gym (at Raleigh facility).
cons: Pay is not competitive to attract and retain best talent.  Department/mid-level management is out of touch with staff.  Department manager does not consider staff input, instead has a very "my-way-or-the-highway" mentality and operational philosophy.  No internal training programs to prepare and develop staff.  You're forced to learn the vast majority of what you will be responsible for as you're doing it, which leads to a lot of errors, double work, and staff frustration.  Very little accountability is imposed upon staff who underperform.  Raises are meager, if you get them--they're called "merit increases" here but everyone complains about the seemingly rigged fashion in which raises are awarded--there is very little difference between the raises of department top performers and bottom performers, so the "merit" system is rather socialist.  Management does a lot of "covering" for each other when one of their ranks does something wrong.

pros: WakeMed has expanded to meet the needs of most of Wake County, making healthcare accessible to nearly everyone, regardless of socioeconomic status, in the community.  Their cardiac program is among the best in the area and the majority of the healthcare staff are extremely knowledgeable and helpful.
cons: The department I worked in was in transition during the time of my employment and was ultimately very poorly managed.  During my 5 years in this department, we went from having no immediate manager to having two within that short period.  Due to the poorly staffed positions, breaks did not exist and even stepping away just to use the bathroom left the employee feeling guilt-ridden.

review_title: Better Management, unless you're in the IT department
pros: Good mission.  Good values.  Great physicians and nurses.  Good Senior Management (except for the IS department)
cons: The "Wake Way" is only followed by the staff at the hospital locations, not in the Operations or Administrative off-site locations, which it should.

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Raleigh, NC
pros: Great medical care, nursing staff and good physicians
cons: Treat their staff poorly, fail to recognize that staff has families and lives outside of work. Coworker called out because daughter was sick and she got counseled by manager suggesting that coworker find someone else to care for child. They entrap employees into taking the bait and then discipline them with threats of termination, recently sent out a phishing email telling employees they were getting a holiday gift and when you clicked on link it recorded your user name so management could track you down. If manager hears you want to transfer departments they write you up and give you a disciplinary level so you can’t transfer jobs, the promise you a set schedule and then 8 months down the road they tell you they are changing your work hours to a horrible shift( due to business needs). Recently started a witch hunt of all employees by doing random drug testing instead of dealing with those individuals ( managers don’t have skill to detect an impaired employee so they institute hospital wide drug testing)

review_title: IF YOPU ARE  AN IT WORKER DO NOT EVEN APPLY HERE.
pros: Almost none. Going home each day and leaving on my last day.
cons:
No real leadership throughout the company.
Zero respect for IT work and workers overall.
No time provided to do the work that needs to be done yet they keep adding sites/applications and services.
The IT Transformation has destroyed the dept. There is no longer any team work or collaboration.
The career ladder should be renamed to the career hole in the ground. Only people who are qualified are much cheaper outside staff.
Unannounced hiring freeze to begin in Oct 2018. This is not just IS but across all sectors.
IT budget is continuously cut and shorted to make up for the VP excess and whims.  
They are now trying to Toyota system. The issue is they are not Toyota. They do not have what it takes to maintain anything. 
The leadership cannot seem to figure out where we are losing money after 10 years of very small, limited raises and nearly no bonus to speak of. 
IUf you need Employment based health benefits, WakeMed will cost you 1000.00 a month for a family plan. If you go to anyone outside of WakeMed your out of pocket costs skyrocket.

review_title: Take it or Leave it , not very nice attitude but WakeMed implies to employees
pros: The staff do an awesome job at keeping things clean and safe for the patients. I do love working here and my intent is to retire here but...
cons:
It is like walking on egg shells around here and you get penalized for not coming to work sick but you aren't supposed to come in if you are sick. Five absences in one years time is ridiculous at best but especially if you work in health field and are exposed to people coughing in the air and being unsanitary in bathrooms. 
It feels like all management cares about now is the bottom line instead of keeping valuable employees who had stood by WakeMed through all its many changes

pros: Pay and friends you will make there
cons: WAY understaffed. Some nurses treat you like a custodian rather than an aide. Management IS HORRIBLE on 2 West Telemetry in Cary location. I am a hard worker and have always been praised at jobs for how I handle things (was even recognized sometimes here) but the entire unit whether it was co-workers or management was literally like going back to high school. I quit for this very reason. No body knows what’s going on hardly ever. Rules for the employees change so often that you can’t get anything straight. The nurse aide to patient ratio (especially on night shift is RIDICULOUS for hospital treated patients) expect 15 by yourself every night with LITTLE help from nurses because they are also busy with their ratios.

review_title: Has Very Good Potential with Improvement
job_title: Patient Account Representative in Raleigh, NC
pros: Good Pay, professional environment, stable work field. They support you furthering your education. Do your job and no worries about job security. Good place to retire if you are content with just pay and not advancing.
cons: Unstable middle management, not much opportunity for growth, don't invest in there good employees that want to excel.  Employee process support is a little lacking.

review_title: I obtained a great deal of knowledge, they made me very marketable.
pros:
I learned a great deal.  If you were willing to learn, there was always someone willing to teach 
you new skills. I made a lot of friends while I worked there, that I still associate with today. They were more like a family, than co-workers.
cons: I worked at Wake  Med Zebulon/Wendell.  The hospital was 50 years old, and needed a lot of updates.  We also didn't have the newest equipment.  The patients received excellent care, and the staff was the best I have ever worked with.  These things made up for the dated building, and equipment.  They had an excellent  benefit package, this may have changed with all of the insurance changes at this time.

review_title: Executives are running a kingdom, not a hospital
pros: Great co-workers, every day is different, competitive pay and benefits.
cons:
Administration is completely and utterly out of control, often wanting special favors or special treatment.  The new CFO has actually demanded workers come to her home and set up IT equipment and other things for her.  What's next, asking EVS to come and clean her house once a week?

This is a hospital, here to save lives, not be your personal slave system.  That type of behavior trickles down to middle management as well.  Slow to praise, quick to discipline.

review_title: It can be a great fit for many, but ....
pros: They are really big on expanding, so there are ample opportunities to change jobs for a better fit if needed. There is an end of the year bonus if the company is doing well which is a percentage of your annual salary. They are really trying hard to make sure that they have the latest technology available for the staff to use.
cons: It is very difficult to find additional employment elsewhere since they are expanding so much. The management seems to have favorites and will even create positions for you if they really like you, and are very hard on those with whom they have personal issues with. Staff are worked alot harder than they should be in an attempt to save money.

review_title: Could be a wonderful hospital if not for some Management.
pros:
Good pay and benefits. Great teamwork within your unit. 
Free parking. 
New technology. 
Major employer in the Raleigh area. 
That's it.
cons:
There's a lot of miscommunication and pettiness between ER and ICU. 
I was an employee for 8 years and management of the last unit I was in ruined the morale of the best co-workers I ever knew. 
MANY of us (long term employees) have resigned over the past year, however no one questions the reason.

Taken on the Disney method of customer service, as a healthcare professional you aren't judge on your skills and abilities to care for patients but on your customer service so then you feel more like a hostess/server/barista than what you went to school for.

review_title: Is the money all that matters?
pros: The pay is definately better than the other hospitals in the area and I can get as much overtime or call time as I want.
cons: I have been here for a year and the department I am in is horrible.  The management shows immense favortism and the manager has been investigated for comments and unprofessional behavior.  He has now left the department but management directly above him is not much better.  I am looking to leave this facility ASAP, even if it means less money.

review_title: Ambitious organization with mild growth pains
pros: One of the best hospitals for encouraging employee ownership. Probably the best doctor nurse communication and mutual respect in the triangle.
cons: As the largest hospital in Raleigh they must be aggressive in limiting competitor's growth in primary referral bases, particularly where they are not a large well known teaching facilitity with the name recognition or range of services UNC or Duke has to offer.

pros: As a baby boomer I've been around the career block a time or two. This is the best place I've ever worked. The CEO is the right person, in the right place at the right time. Very values based. "The Wake Way" is an accountability standard you see woven into everything this employer does. One of the few I've worked for where the mission statement is more than a plaque on the door. It's a way of life.
cons: A somewhat conservative benefit plan; could be more creative with opportunity to select benefits most important to the individual. However the plan is typical of healthcare in general.

review_title: Not the WakeMed it used to be
pros: Job security, heart program, and community outreach programs.
cons:
Ineffectual and inexperienced managers who get promoted because they have advanced degrees and NO actual real-world experience. 
If you leave and want to return, they will not even give you an interview because they can replace you with 1-2 full-time new nurses for what you were making.
Ageism is alive and well here.

pros: Free Parking. Flexible schedule. Usually great co-workers.
cons: There is no defense against demanding/confrontational/physically aggressive patients or family members. It's all about "Customer Service" We have to kiss ass and "just deal with it". More time is spent making sure family is comfortable/happy than actually taking care of patients. So many policy changes and equipment changes made WITHOUT actually asking the RN's who do all the work any input.Management does show favoritism.

review_title: float pool pediatric ICU, pediatric med-surg
pros: hourly rate with float pool (that's if you get scheduled).
cons: Not enough hours to work full time as float pool staff in Pediatric specialty. Full time hours advertised yet has been a challenge to get hours to make the increased hourly rate worth it.  Plus no benefits offered for float pool staff even with working full time hours. If I want to work and the need is there, I should get hospital benefits. Or at least offer to pay out of pocket with discounted rate for insurance.

pros: Great people, good communication between departments.  Work hours are somewhat flexible and I have no trouble getting vacation or time off when I need it.  People are generally nice and supportive.  Patient care comes first.
cons: Salary is on the low side with little opportunity to negotiate for a raise.  Upper management is somewhat out of touch with the average staff. Staff sometimes feel underpaid raises are on the low side.  The difference between a poor review and a great review is only a few cents.

pros: The hospital is, in itself, a good place to work.  The CEO is trying to recover from the economic downturn, and the advent of the Affordable Care Act.
cons: The management of the Clinical Laboratory is guided by favoritism.  Certain staff cause undue stress on peers causing a hostile work environment.  Nursing received a major pay increase, while other staff received a minor wage "adjustment", while also adding that adjustment to nursing on top of their wage increase.

job_title: Inpatient Rehab Therapist in Raleigh, NC
pros: My co-workers were great, and I loved my "team."
cons:
-We were told in a meeting that WakeMed was cutting back several employee benefits / perks because, when compared to similar facilities, they found they were going "above and beyond" for their employees and decided to make certain cuts. The reason I started working are WM was because of those benefits / perks. No employee is going to want to go "above and beyond" for an employer that doesn't go "above and beyond" for their employees.
-I was pressured into getting my time with my patients when they were sick and unable to participate in therapy that day. I was told to "figure it out" and that "maybe I wasn't trying hard enough." Mind you, this was told to me about patients that had thrown up / passed out / etc. during the session (which was known).
-When others were off (whether it was expected or not), most of the time we didn't have coverage; therefore, we had to often double (and sometimes triple) patients just to make sure all patients got their time. Just an FYI, most patients don't like that.
-My director missed two scheduled meeting with me. Both times her secretary informed me that she was in other meetings.
-Overall, just about everyone felt that WakeMed doesn't value its employees, and that "money" is more important that even the patients' needs and wants. Another FYI, the people I keep in touch with that still work at WM, continue to feel this way.
-No room for growth
-No reimbursement for CECs  
-I have many more, but I think "you" get the picture.

pros: If parking is one of the things people list as a "pro" in most reviews something isn't right.
cons: To many to list but here's a start....if you aren't in the "Click" watch out! Hostile work environment, they try to ruin your day/work life if you aren't "in" with the right managers, write ups are used as weapons and petty in cases more often than not, limit your advancement/potential and then tell you that you aren't doing enough, in many instances I've heard of and my personal experience the job you interview for is NOTHING like what they ask you to do, put some under microscopes while others can do no wrong. I could go on but a 3.1 rating says a lot in my eyes. Have worked for much larger and much smaller companies but have never seen such blatant displays of terrible management and "playing favorites" in 20+ years of work. When it's all said and done it's a paycheck. That's all. Are you willing to feel like a soulless shell of a human for that? Be treated like a child? Condemned for asking a question or not being a kiss up? Because that's what they want. I have worked in over 50 hospitals in my previous employment with a large healthcare vendor all over the country and Wakemed certainly tops the list for being one of the most easy to see flaws and practices. DONT DO IT! You can do better than this environment. Even if you are terrible at your job you can live like royalty as long as you kiss the right a**. That's not fair to the people who try, who care and who work their tails off just to be written up because the dept head doesn't ask you to sit at their table in the overpriced cafeteria. DONT DO IT!!!

pros: Overtime hours are often available since the hospital is always busy. The Cafeteria food is good  as well as the atmosphere is the cafeteria. Management always looking for ways to improve moral and productivity

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant in Raleigh, NC

review_title: HORRIBLE PLACE TO WORK, MANAGEMENT RETALIATES AGAINST EMPLOYEES, BULLYING
pros: do not have to work weekends in some departments.
cons: Management is unprofessional, bullying, threatens employees, never has anything good to say about an employee that is not their favorite employee, sneaky, vindictive, unfair, discriminate, treat you like first graders as though you know nothing, hostile, constantly making up new rules outside of wakemed's corporate policy, always conspiring behind your back trying to find something to write you up for if you are not their favorite employee and if they have a bad day they take it out on you! Some managers have been there for years & gets aware with mistreating employees while upper management covers up the misdoings. They stressed the "WakeWay Policy" they do not follow or adhere to. If you report them to HR they cover up all negative claims banning up with the reported manager you file a complaint on and reprimand you instead with level 1 or up disciplinary action. They try to force you to quit by making your life miserable daily while working. They will act very friendly during the interview & the first 90 days of you being hired. Then watch out from that point on it's downhill. Some managers force their employees to make complaints about a fellow employee that the manager wants to get rid of & if you do not say something negative then you are on their hit list in addition said managers still add your name to the complaint when trying to state their case to their direct higher up manager or director.
